topic.title: Discussion: HW-M9
topic.msg:
Post questions about HW-M9. Use the first line of your post as the subject of the post.

Assignments: Section 8.11 probs 1,2,4 5, 6, 7

entry.title: married llama
entry.msg:
Clarify problem 6. Exchanging Integers

It says to swap consecutive pairs of integers but I'm wondering if we iterate through elements by one or two.

INPUT: 1, 2, 3, 4

SWAP ELEMENTS: 2,3,4,1 - next pair is at current index + 1

SWAP AS PAIRS: 2,1,4,3 - next pair is at current index + 2

It's only a minor difference and neither is harder than the other but what is the requirement?

entry.title: supposed squirrel
entry.msg: I'd probably say two, at least that makes more sense to me.

entry.title: unsightly toad
entry.msg: Ya I also thought it was 2.

entry.title: striking snipe
entry.msg: 8.4.6 example referred in #6 using DWORD. If you are using DWORD as well, then I think it should be currentIndex + 4

entry.title: encouraging dragon
entry.msg: Agree with others above, I think you had the right idea in mind with the current index +2 but like Naresh mentioned be wary of the type of element. It is probably safe to get used to doing TYPE var1 * 2 or smtg similiar.

entry.title: constitutional cattle
entry.msg: Definitely iterating them through two would be easier as you'd only need to deal with consecutive pairs so iterating by 1 would probably be counterintuitive.

entry.title: near mastodon
entry.msg: 2 will be much easier and I believe that 2 was the intended incrementation. Double-check with the professor tho.

entry.title: clean bovid
entry.msg: I think 2 too.

entry.title: inland hummingbird
entry.msg: I also think 2

entry.title: electric dolphin
entry.msg: Same. I also think 2.

entry.title: pleased orca
entry.msg: Pretty sure you're supposed to iterate by two.

entry.title: broad bird
entry.msg: Yes, I also think 2 as well.

entry.title: alert ant
entry.msg: My answer is 2

entry.title: dry cuckoo
entry.msg:
Very basic question:

PUSH ebx -> save register values

POP ebx -> restore register values

One of the homework assignments requires (Preserve all registers (except EAX) that are modified by the procedure).

Preserve in this context means PUSH? The more I read it the more I think it is POP. Confused.

Your understanding? Thanks!

entry.title: thoughtless swordtail
entry.msg: When they say preserve registers, they mean to push the registers you will modify at the beginning of the procedure (after you have created your stack frame) and pop the registers you modify at the end of the procedure (before you leave the stack frame). You can also use the USES keyword to preserve the registers which will do the same thing as I mentioned, however, I doubt we will be able to use it in the final exam. Also, the homework asks you to use MASM parameters and I think pushing and popping registers manually doesn't play well with the MASM parameters and you should use USES.

entry.title: forward frog
entry.msg:
To clarify the usage of push and pop in a procedure.

mov eax, 10

Test1 PROC

Push eax ; saves the value of eax =10  when modified.

add eax, 10

mov ecx, eax ; eax is added to loop counter

pop eax ; eax is now 10 since new eax is poped and not used.

In this case eax is preserved its value outside of the PROC

entry.title: dry cuckoo
entry.msg: Thanks, Ronak and Steven! Your responses confirmed my further reading and understanding through going through the homework. Much appreciated!

entry.title: similar salamander
entry.msg: Are there any restricted directives or shortcuts we aren't allowed to use in the homework?

entry.title: forward frog
entry.msg: Anything that isnt taught in the lectures or textbook. Feel free to use any tools that are helpful to you, but remember to check if a question clarifies suing a specific library or instruction.

entry.title: total takin
entry.msg: Protip: as enticing as it is, don't use rol!

entry.title: robust quail
entry.msg:
Q2:

How did you guys approach this probelm? This is the Chess Board question

entry.title: Cole Gannon
entry.msg: For each row, you keep some running state (either in a register or otherwise) of what the last color you wrote was. Then you toggle it for each tile. In between rows, you toggle the state once more to create the checkerboard effect.

entry.title: broken bird
entry.msg: Thanks for the help, Cole! I was also unsure of how to approach this problem.

entry.title: broad bird
entry.msg: Thanks for the help Cole, I was unsure of this problem as well.

entry.title: Deleted by encouraging dragon on Aug 1 at 4:23pm
grand gopher
entry.msg: Does anyone have a good resource for the euclids algorithm, the textbook just says search on the web which is a bit broad, I might be overthinking it but this was the only HW question that might have been pretty hard.

entry.title: evident earwig
entry.msg: Euclid's algorithm basically states that if a>b, then gcd(a,b) = gcd(a-b,b), so basically you need to do recursion, and if one of the numbers is 0, the other number is the gcd (return value).

entry.title: early deer
entry.msg:
Hi Aaron,

Khan Academy has a really nice explanation of the Euclidean Algorithm along with some examples.

https://www.khanacademy.org/computing/computer-science/cryptography/modarithmetic/a/the-euclidean-algorithm

entry.title: gradual gopher
entry.msg:
Exchanging Integers
Create an array of randomly ordered integers. Using the Swap procedure from Section 8.4.6 as a
tool, write a loop that exchanges each consecutive pair of integers in the array.
